with a standard sun vm rather than j9?  If so then we'd like to try this in 
order to eliminate (?) the possibility of this being a j9 locking bug.

It doesn't seem possible.  I tried running an AWT testcase using the standard 
JDK, putting our AWT and SWT ahead of the JDK in the bootpath (using Eclipse).  
I got the following error message in the console:

java.lang.ExceptionInInitializerError: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at java.awt.Component.<clinit>(Component.java:155)
	at TestAwt.main(TestAwt.java:6)
Exception in thread "main" 

Pat, is this consistent with your expectations?

No, it's not consistent.  In fact, I've run in the past this way (prepend our 
AWT in front of Sun's, and run under the Sun VM).  In fact, so co-op in PHX 
reported this a week or two ago as well.  We should be able to do this, unless, 
of course, there is a really, really good reason we can't.  In other words, 
what is the Component static initializer actually doing that's killing us?

However, it seems unlikely the original problem reported has anything to do 
with "problems with j9 locking".  Differences in timing, sure.  For a long time 
the SWT natives were reaching into things the wrong way.  Basically, caching 
JNIEnv's.  It wouldn't hurt to pass the natives over to one of those weasel-ish 
characters to see if there is anything obviously unkosher about them.  I'd say 
focus on the callback stuff ...

BTW, this message sounds awfully familiar, like something we've seen a year or 
more ago on Motif ...

- it would be nice if Silenio wasn't on vacation <g>
Not surprising you can go back that far - as Pat said, this seems familiar from

this has prevented us from elevating AWT for Motif from "beta" status.
I'm quite sure that the cause here is a j9 problem which has been recently 
fixed, because:

- this problem no longer occurs with the 0816 j9, though it did consistently 
with the 0719 j9
- an identical problem that Christophe previously looked at here with running 
the Caffeine tests no longer occurs with the 0816 j9, though it did 
consistently with the 0719 j9
- I asked some weasels...
Can you look at http://dev.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=22024 ?  This 
problem has gone away since switching to the 0816 J9 drop (previous J9 drop 
that was showing the problem was 0719).  Do you think any of the changes made 
between these two drops could have resulted in this problem being fixed?  Or 
are we now just getting lucky due to some change in timing?
- ...and got two responses, the first one...
(Roo) I remember getting pulled in to look at this with John D.  If I recall 
correctly the problem didn't happen with the JIT turned off. (however no 
mention of any change in behaviour if we turned off the JIT or not in the PR).  
We did fix a bug in the JIT that in some circumstances it was optimizing away 
the monitor in a static synchronized native.  If this was the case in your 
code, then it is possible that we did fix the actual problem -- however, from 
the PR there isn't enough information for me to make anything better than a 
guess. [Note: swt's OS class is all static synchronized natives, and the 
problem only occurred in 0719 with JIT turned on]
- ... the second ...
(John D) The error was "Xlib: unexpected async reply (sequence 0x3c68)!" which 
looks thread/synchronized related and the JIT bug was removing these sync call 
so looks like a good bet.
